metadata.subject: Mathematics
metadata.curriculumSubtopic: Real-world applications, financial literacy, scientific calculations, practical problem solving

questions.question: Emma has $45 to spend on books. Each book costs $8. How many books can she buy, and how much money will she have left over?
questions.explanation: 45 ÷ 8 = 5 remainder 5. She can buy 5 books (5 × $8 = $40) and will have $45 - $40 = $5 left over.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Emma $45 books $8 each how many left over? Money calculations: 5 books, $5 left.

questions.question: A recipe calls for 3/4 cup of flour to make 12 cookies. How much flour is needed to make 24 cookies?
questions.explanation: 24 cookies is double 12 cookies, so we need double the flour: 3/4 × 2 = 6/4 = 1 1/2 cups.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Recipe 3/4 cup flour 12 cookies, how much for 24? Recipe scaling: 1 1/2 cups.

questions.question: A rectangular garden is 8 meters long and 5 meters wide. If fencing costs $12 per meter, how much will it cost to fence the entire garden?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 2(length + width) = 2(8 + 5) = 2(13) = 26 meters. Cost = 26 × $12 = $312.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Garden 8m×5m fencing $12 per meter total cost? Perimeter costs: $312.

questions.question: Sarah saves $25 each month. How much will she have saved after 8 months?
questions.explanation: Total savings = $25 × 8 months = $200.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Sarah saves $25 monthly, how much after 8 months? Savings calculation: $200.

questions.question: A water tank holds 240 liters when full. If it's currently 3/4 full, how many liters of water are in the tank?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Water tank 240L, 3/4 full how many liters? Volume fractions: 180 liters.

questions.question: A school bus travels 15 kilometers to school and the same distance back home. If it makes this trip 5 days a week, how many kilometers does it travel in total each week?
questions.explanation: Daily distance = 15 + 15 = 30 km. Weekly distance = 30 × 5 = 150 km.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Bus 15km to school, back home, 5 days week total? Travel distance: 150km.

questions.question: Tom's family uses 125 kWh of electricity per month. If electricity costs 20 cents per kWh, what is their monthly electricity bill?
questions.explanation: Total cost = 125 kWh × $0.20 = $25.00.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 125 kWh electricity 20 cents per kWh monthly bill? Utility costs: $25.

questions.question: A pizza is cut into 8 equal slices. If 3 friends eat 2 slices each, what fraction of the pizza is left?
questions.explanation: Friends ate 3 × 2 = 6 slices. Remaining = 8 - 6 = 2 slices. Fraction left = 2/8 = 1/4.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Pizza 8 slices, 3 friends eat 2 each, fraction left? Food fractions: 1/4.

questions.question: A parking meter charges $2.50 for the first hour and $1.75 for each additional hour. How much does it cost to park for 4 hours?
questions.explanation: First hour: $2.50. Additional 3 hours: 3 × $1.75 = $5.25. Total: $2.50 + $5.25 = $7.75.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Parking $2.50 first hour, $1.75 each additional, 4 hours cost? Parking fees: $7.75.

questions.question: A basketball team scored 18, 24, 21, and 27 points in their last 4 games. What was their average score per game?
questions.explanation: Total points = 18 + 24 + 21 + 27 = 90. Average = 90 ÷ 4 = 22.5 points per game.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Basketball scores 18,24,21,27 points, average per game? Sports statistics: 22.5 points.

questions.question: Maya wants to buy a bicycle that costs $180. She has saved $75 and plans to save $15 each week. How many weeks will it take her to have enough money?
questions.explanation: Amount still needed = $180 - $75 = $105. Time needed = $105 ÷ $15 per week = 7 weeks.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Maya bicycle $180, saved $75, saves $15 weekly, how many weeks? Savings planning: 7 weeks.

questions.question: A movie theater has 24 rows with 18 seats in each row. If 75% of the seats are filled, how many people are watching the movie?
questions.explanation: Total seats = 24 × 18 = 432. People watching = 75% of 432 = 0.75 × 432 = 324 people.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Theater 24 rows 18 seats each, 75% filled, how many people? Theater capacity: 324 people.

questions.question: A school is planning a field trip. The bus rental costs $350, and admission to the museum is $8 per student. If there are 45 students going, what is the total cost per student?
questions.explanation: Museum admission = 45 × $8 = $360. Total cost = $350 + $360 = $710. Cost per student = $710 ÷ 45 = $15.78.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Field trip bus $350, museum $8 per student, 45 students, cost per student? Trip planning: $15.78.

questions.question: A farmer has a rectangular field that is 120m by 80m. He wants to plant corn in 60% of the field and soybeans in the rest. What area will be planted with soybeans?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Field 120m×80m, 60% corn rest soybeans, soybean area? Farming area: 3,840 m².

questions.question: Lisa is comparing two cell phone plans. Plan A costs $45 per month plus $0.10 per text. Plan B costs $60 per month with unlimited texts. How many texts would she need to send for both plans to cost the same?
questions.explanation: Let x = number of texts. Plan A cost: $45 + $0.10x. For equal costs: $45 + $0.10x = $60. $0.10x = $15. x = 150 texts.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Cell plan A $45+$0.10 per text, Plan B $60 unlimited, same cost how many texts? Plan comparison: 150 texts.

questions.question: A swimming pool is being filled with water. It currently contains 2,400 liters and is being filled at a rate of 180 liters per hour. How long will it take to reach its capacity of 4,800 liters?
questions.explanation: Water needed = 4,800 - 2,400 = 2,400 liters. Time = 2,400 ÷ 180 = 13.33 hours = 13 hours 20 minutes.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Pool 2,400L, filling 180L/hour, reach 4,800L capacity how long? Rate calculations: 13h 20min.

questions.question: A store is having a 20% off sale on all items. If Jake buys a jacket originally priced at $85 and pays 8% sales tax on the discounted price, how much does he pay in total?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Jacket $85, 20% off sale, 8% tax on discounted price, total paid? Shopping calculations: $73.44.

questions.question: A recipe for fruit punch serves 8 people and calls for 2 1/4 cups of orange juice, 1 1/2 cups of pineapple juice, and 3/4 cup of cranberry juice. How much of each juice is needed to serve 12 people?
questions.answer: Orange: 3 3/8 cups, Pineapple: 2 1/4 cups, Cranberry: 1 1/8 cups
questions.explanation: Scale factor = 12 ÷ 8 = 1.5. Orange: 2 1/4 × 1.5 = 3 3/8 cups. Pineapple: 1 1/2 × 1.5 = 2 1/4 cups. Cranberry: 3/4 × 1.5 = 1 1/8 cups.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Punch recipe serves 8, scale to 12 people, juice amounts? Recipe scaling: 3 3/8, 2 1/4, 1 1/8 cups.

questions.question: An online store charges $4.99 shipping for orders under $50 and free shipping for orders $50 or more. Emma wants to buy 3 books at $16.95 each. Should she buy all 3 books in one order or separately to minimize cost?
questions.answer: Buy all 3 books in one order to save money
questions.explanation: 3 books cost: 3 × $16.95 = $50.85. One order: $50.85 (free shipping). Three separate orders: 3 × ($16.95 + $4.99) = 3 × $21.94 = $65.82. Save $14.97 buying together.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Books $16.95 each, $4.99 shipping under $50, free over $50, buy 3 together or separate? Shopping strategy: Together cheaper.

questions.question: A city's recycling program shows that 18% of household waste is recyclable paper, 12% is recyclable plastic, and 8% is recyclable glass. If a family produces 45 kg of waste per week, how much could they recycle?
questions.explanation: Total recyclable = 18% + 12% + 8% = 38%. Recyclable amount = 38% of 45 kg = 0.38 × 45 = 17.1 kg.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Recycling 18% paper, 12% plastic, 8% glass, family 45kg waste weekly, how much recyclable? Environmental math: 17.1kg.

questions.question: A car travels 420 kilometers on 35 liters of gasoline. If gasoline costs $1.45 per liter, what is the cost per kilometer to operate this car?
questions.explanation: Fuel efficiency = 420 km ÷ 35 L = 12 km/L. Cost per liter = $1.45. Cost per km = $1.45 ÷ 12 = $0.12 per km.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Car 420km on 35L gas, gas $1.45/L, cost per kilometer? Transportation costs: $0.12/km.

questions.question: A survey of 240 students found that 45% play soccer, 30% play basketball, and 15% play both sports. How many students play neither soccer nor basketball?
questions.explanation: Soccer only: 45% - 15% = 30%. Basketball only: 30% - 15% = 15%. Both: 15%. Total playing sports: 30% + 15% + 15% = 60%. Neither: 100% - 60% = 40%. 40% of 240 = 96 students.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: 240 students, 45% soccer, 30% basketball, 15% both, how many neither? Survey analysis: 96 students.

questions.question: A construction company needs to fence a triangular lot with sides measuring 60m, 80m, and 100m. If fencing costs $18 per meter including installation, what is the total cost?
questions.explanation: Perimeter = 60 + 80 + 100 = 240 meters. Total cost = 240 × $18 = $4,320.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Triangle lot 60m, 80m, 100m sides, fencing $18/m, total cost? Construction costs: $4,320.

questions.question: A bank offers 3% annual interest on savings accounts. If Maria deposits $800 and leaves it for 2 years without withdrawing anything, how much will she have in total?
questions.explanation: Simple interest = Principal × Rate × Time = $800 × 0.03 × 2 = $48. Total amount = $800 + $48 = $848.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Bank 3% annual interest, Maria deposits $800 for 2 years, total amount? Banking interest: $848.

questions.question: A school cafeteria serves 1,200 students daily. They want to reduce food waste by 25% over 6 months. Currently, they waste 15% of prepared food. If they achieve their goal, how much food (as a percentage) will they waste daily?
questions.explanation: Current waste: 15%. Target reduction: 25% of current waste = 25% of 15% = 0.25 × 15% = 3.75%. New waste rate: 15% - 3.75% = 11.25%.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.curriculumSubtopic: Waste reduction and percentage of percentage
questions.contentForEmbedding: Cafeteria wastes 15% food, reduce waste by 25%, new waste percentage? Waste reduction: 11.25%.

questions.question: A manufacturing company produces widgets at different rates on different machines. Machine A produces 150 widgets per hour, Machine B produces 200 widgets per hour, and Machine C produces 180 widgets per hour. If they run all three machines for 6.5 hours, how many widgets do they produce in total?
questions.explanation: Machine A: 150 × 6.5 = 975 widgets. Machine B: 200 × 6.5 = 1,300 widgets. Machine C: 180 × 6.5 = 1,170 widgets. Total: 975 + 1,300 + 1,170 = 3,445 widgets.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Machines A 150/h, B 200/h, C 180/h widgets, run 6.5 hours, total production? Manufacturing rates: 3,445 widgets.

questions.question: A city water department charges residents based on usage tiers: first 10,000 liters at $0.80 per 1,000L, next 15,000L at $1.20 per 1,000L, and anything over 25,000L at $1.60 per 1,000L. What would a family pay for using 32,000 liters in a month?
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.curriculumSubtopic: Tiered pricing systems and utility bills

questions.question: A solar panel installation on a house generates an average of 28 kWh per day. The family uses 32 kWh per day on average. They can sell excess electricity back to the grid at $0.12 per kWh and buy electricity at $0.18 per kWh. What is their net monthly electricity cost (30 days)?
questions.explanation: Daily shortage: 32 - 28 = 4 kWh. Monthly shortage: 4 × 30 = 120 kWh. Cost: 120 × $0.18 = $21.60 per month.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.curriculumSubtopic: Solar energy economics and net metering
questions.contentForEmbedding: Solar 28 kWh/day, use 32 kWh/day, sell $0.12/kWh, buy $0.18/kWh, monthly cost? Solar economics: $21.60.

questions.question: A delivery service has trucks that can carry a maximum of 2,500 kg. They need to deliver packages weighing 180 kg, 240 kg, 320 kg, 150 kg, 280 kg, 190 kg, 350 kg, and 220 kg. What is the minimum number of trucks needed, and how should the packages be distributed?
questions.explanation: Total weight: 180+240+320+150+280+190+350+220 = 1,930 kg. Although this fits in one truck's capacity (2,500 kg), optimal loading: Truck 1: 350+320+280+240 = 1,190 kg. Truck 2: 220+190+180+150 = 740 kg. Both loads are under 2,500 kg limit.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Delivery trucks 2,500kg max, packages 180,240,320,150,280,190,350,220 kg, minimum trucks needed? Logistics optimization: 2 trucks.

questions.question: A greenhouse owner wants to maximize profit from tomato and cucumber plants. Tomatoes require 2 square meters each and yield $15 profit per plant. Cucumbers require 1.5 square meters each and yield $8 profit per plant. If the greenhouse has 120 square meters available, how many of each plant should be grown for maximum profit?
questions.answer: 60 tomato plants for maximum profit of $900
questions.explanation: Profit per square meter: Tomatoes = $15 ÷ 2 = $7.50/m². Cucumbers = $8 ÷ 1.5 = $5.33/m². Since tomatoes are more profitable per square meter, plant only tomatoes: 120 ÷ 2 = 60 tomato plants. Profit = 60 × $15 = $900.
questions.subject: Mathematics
questions.contentForEmbedding: Greenhouse 120m², tomatoes 2m² $15 profit, cucumbers 1.5m² $8 profit, maximize profit plan? Profit optimization: 60 tomatoes, $900.
